title: Question 77

children: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for severe headache and blurred vision of 8 hours' duration. She is 35 weeks pregnant. She has no history of hypertension. Her only medication is a multivitamin.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 200/110 mm Hg, pulse rate is 90/min, and respiration rate is 20/min.

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)

children: is 96% with the patient breathing ambient air. No focal neurologic deficits are noted.
of 600 mg/g. Aminotransferase levels are normal.
Blood pressure is reduced to 180/100 mm Hg with intravenous labetalol.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

In patients who are at or beyond 34 weeks' gestation and who develop preeclampsia with severe features, emergent management of severe hypertension and prompt delivery are recommended to avoid maternal and fetal complications.
The most appropriate next step in management for this patient with preeclampsia is delivery (

). Preeclampsia is a disorder of pregnancy that is associated with new-onset hypertension, most often occurring after 20 weeks of gestation. Although hypertension is often accompanied by new-onset proteinuria, some women present with hypertension and signs or symptoms of end-organ dysfunction without proteinuria. The presence of one or more of the following findings of end-organ dysfunction indicates a diagnosis of preeclampsia with severe features: thrombocytopenia (<100,000/μL [100 × 10

/L]); liver enzyme levels twice the upper limit of normal; severe persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain not accounted for by alternative diagnoses; kidney injury (serum creatinine concentration >1.1 mg/dL [97.2 μmol/L] or a doubling of the serum creatinine concentration in the absence of another kidney disease); pulmonary edema; or new-onset headache unresponsive to acetaminophen and not accounted for by alternative diagnoses or visual disturbance. Patients with preeclampsia are also at risk of developing HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count), which has been associated with increased rates of maternal morbidity and mortality. Definitive treatment of severe preeclampsia in patients who are at or beyond 34 weeks' gestation includes emergent management of severe hypertension and prompt delivery.

) to promote fetal lung maturity should be administered before 34 weeks of gestation for a patient with nonsevere preeclampsia in whom delivery in the next 7 days is anticipated. Delivery should not be delayed for the administration of glucocorticoids in the late preterm period.

), are teratogenic and should be avoided during pregnancy. Recommended first-line antihypertensives for urgent blood pressure control in pregnancy include intravenous labetalol, intravenous hydralazine, and immediate-release nifedipine.

) is recommended only for hypertensive emergencies resistant to first-line therapy and the presence of end-organ damage. When used, it should be infused for the shortest amount of time possible because of cyanide and thiocyanate toxicity risk in the patient and fetus or newborn. Sodium nitroprusside can also be associated with increased intracranial pressure with potential worsening of cerebral edema in the patient.

references: Gestational hypertension and preeclampsia: ACOG practice bulletin, number 222. Obstet Gynecol. 2020;135:e237-e260.
